Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Nonparametric smoothing for data with multiple components
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over the decades, nonparametric smoothing has become a standard tool for many classical statistical problems owing partly to the boom of computing power. Relatively little work has addressed nonparametric smoothing in more complex settings where data have multiple components and the analysis requires nontrivial integration of techniques from different statistical domains. This project concerns three types of such complex data that are common in practice, and propose a suite of nonparametric statistical models in the framework of smoothing spline ANOVA models. Existing methods for these three types of data are mainly parametric and semi-parametric, whose practical uses are limited by their strong assumptions on the dependence structure of response on predictors or covariates. The nonparametric methods proposed in this project, combining nonparametric Gaussian regression, nonparametric logistic regression and nonparametric hazard rate estimation, offer much more flexibility and are extremely useful at the exploratory stage when researchers are not certain of the pattern of dependence. Accompanied with the proposed models are useful inference tools such as model selection and confidence intervals. Asymptotic properties of the estimates are investigated through a combination of asymptotic analysis techniques for nonparametric smoothing splines, semiparametric estimation, and measurement error models.



Major challenges to today's federal government, such as health care reform, education reform and financial system improvement, provide data with complex structures that call for accurate, informative and flexible data analysis methods. The proposed nonparametric smoothing methods provide an innovative direction for developing analysis tools appropriate for tackling these challenges. These types of data can also be found in a broad spectrum of scientific fields such as biological sciences, economics, social sciences, psychological sciences, and biomedical studies. This research will advance education and training of graduate and undergraduate students in the relevant statistical areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
As data become larger and more complex in all the fields, the federal government has realized the necessity of making decisions based on accurate and informative data analysis. Health care reform needs an effective and comparative analysis on health care expenses to reveal contributing factors to skyrocketing health care spending. Education reform needs a thorough analysis of academic records to figure out what works and what doesn't. Improvement on the stability of financial systems needs rigorous and accurate tracking of major financial units’ performance data. Common in all these tasks is the complexity of the data involved. They often have multiple components that require integration of analysis techniques from different statistical domains. They often show irregular patterns that defy any strict forms of assumptions commonly made in parametric or semi-parametric methods. The nonparametric methods developed from this project for data with multiple components provide exactly the kind of appropriate analysis tools for such tasks.

 

Comparing with the existing parametric and semiparametric methods, the nonparametric models developed from this project make much milder assumptions that are more likely to hold in practice. And they often yield more accurate and visually appealing smooth estimates. The developed statistical analysis tools can be applied to a wide range of areas including biological sciences, economics, social sciences, psychological sciences, and biomedical studies, where these specific types of data are common. The developed analysis tools, available through requests to the PI, provide useful extension to the existing software, such as the R packages assist, gss, and mgcv.

 

The success of the proposal has also promoted students' interests in relevant statistical courses at the PI's institution. These courses include Nonparametric Function Estimation, Survival Analysis, Functional Data Analysis, Longitudinal Data Analysis, Semiparametric Models, and Measurement Error Models. The training provided by the courses has been producing motivating students who can further research and applications in these fields. For example, the PI has supervised a PhD in Statistics who has been a Senior Biostatistician at Novartis Oncology since 2010. All the results from the project have been disseminated through journal articles and presentations at national and international meetings.
